treatment.description: Plants to 4 dm; roots elongate, fleshily woody. Stems ± erect, usually branching. Leaves sessile; blade terete, to 7 cm. Inflores-cences cymose, much overtopping leaves; peduncle scapelike, to 20 cm. Flowers: sepals deciduous, ovate, 3–4 mm; petals pink to rose-purple, obovate, 9–15 mm; stamens (40–)50–100; stigma 1, subcapitate. Capsules subglobose, sometimes trigonous, 3–4 mm. Seeds without arcuate ridges, 0.8–1 mm. 2n = 24, 48.
treatment.discussion: Most populations of Phemeranthus mengesii are diploid but a few scattered in western Georgia are tetraploid, probably the result of autopolyploidy (W. H. Murdy and M. E. B. Carter 2001).

references.reference: Carter, M. E. B. and W. H. Murdy. 1986. Divergence for sexual and asexual reproductive characters in Talinum mengesii (Portulacaceae). Bull. Torrey Bot. Club 113: 259–267.
